name: Charles Kimbrough
subtitle: US actor, Murphy Brown
blurb: AEIOU actor Charles Kimbrough starred as Jim Dial in TV's Murphy Brown, with Candice Bergen, whose husband LOUIS MALLE is also supervocalic. He won a Tony and met his wife Beth Howland - Vera from TV's Alice in the original cast of Company, making him one of 3 Sondheim performers on our list.

name: Alexis DuPont
subtitle: 19th century French opera tenor
blurb: Clearly one of the lesser known on the list, with Alfred I. Dupont making a strong claim for the title in this slot.

name: Walter Gropius
subtitle: German-born architect, Bauhaus founder
blurb: Taught supervocalic spy and bon vivant EDITH TUDOR HART.

name: Father Coughlin
subtitle: 1930s priest
blurb: Used radio to spread his message of "Social Justice", a term he popularized. And if "real names only" are allowed - well, his name is CHARLES, so... also good for this slot.

name: Anne Hutchinson
subtitle: Early US religious advocate.
blurb: Held firm that persons could be "saved" by the spirit of the Holy Ghost, and that works wouldn't save someone, causing the Antinomian Controversy in 17th century Boston.

name: Ja'Net Dubois
subtitle: US actress, Good Times
blurb: Ja’Net Dubois – Willona from TV’s Good Times - won our hearts not just for her neighborly no-nonsense behavior, and for the head-scratching apostrophe in her name, but for belting out the Jeffersons theme - one of the best in history. She edges out barfly Charles Bukowski, and MANFRED S. LUBOWITZ - better known as Manfred Mann, who at 16 letters is the longest supervocalic with no repeated letters.

name: Annie Proulx
subtitle: US author, The Shipping News
blurb: Also wrote the short story Brokeback Mountain. We cannot quit her, even though she sometimes goes by "E Annie Proulx".

name: Van Lingle Mungo
subtitle: US MLB 1931-1945
blurb: Van Lingo Mungo for the name value, over talk show host Craig Ferguson and short story writer Alice Munro.

name: Martin Brodeur
subtitle: NHL goalie 1991-2003
blurb: One of the best goalies of all time, with the nost NHL wins over 21 seasons for the New Jersey Devils. Other supervocalic goalies include Richard Brodeur, and the last name VANBIESBROUCK.

name: David Souter
subtitle: US Supreme Counrt Justice
blurb: This slot is fertile - though we must give the nod to a Supreme Court justice, we note Oscar winner David O Russell, Obama advisor David Plouffe, iPhone reviewer David Pogue, and Disney animator Hamilton Luske.

name: David Huddleston
subtitle: US Actor, The Big Lebowski
blurb: He was the Lebowski himself, as well as the mayor in Blazing Saddles ("Not only was that authentic frontied gibberish...") - two small but cherished American film roles.

name: Patti LuPone
subtitle: US actress, Evita
blurb: Won the 1979 Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical,  while LEN CARIOU won Best Actor, and also became known for her performance of LADIES WHO LUNCH from Sondheim's Company.

name: Flat-Top the Brick Truck
subtitle: Character, Starlight Express
blurb: Two new discoveries this time around - FLAT-TOP THE BRICK TRUCK, a character from Starlight Express, takes the crown over Dutch Latin scholar MACROPEDIUS, though the awesomeness of that name abounds. (No, Flat-Top is technically not human - no, for the very near "Perfect 5" - a 5-word example, where each word contains 1 vowel - we accommodate.)

name: Jack Joseph Puig
subtitle: US music producer
blurb: Despite his dozens of producing credits, it is his work producing Jellyfish's debut album that gets Jack Joseph Puig the slot - with no real contenders in sight.

name: Francoise Durr
subtitle: Tennis French Open winner, 1967
blurb: Being the last French woman to do win the French Open until Mary Pierce in 2000 solidifies FRANCOISE DURR's supremacy over this slot.

name: Carson Smith McCullers
subtitle: US author, The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter
blurb: At 20 letters, the longest well-known supervocalic person.

name: Paco Underhill
subtitle: US consultant & author, Why We Buy
blurb: Edging out MLB player CARLOS QUENTIN, 15 years after the original list, we find no one more famous than author PACO UNDERHILL for the AOUEI slot.

name: Arlo Guthrie
subtitle: US singer, Alice's Restaurant
blurb: It will take more than Rugrats voice artist KATH SOUCIE to knock the beloved ARLO GUTHRIE off his AOUIE crown.

name: Samuel Wilson
subtitle: US meatpacker - "Uncle Sam
blurb: The supposed model for "Uncle Sam" is one of the more ubiquitous visual figures in US history, though Tour De France winner LAURENT FIGNON and physicist ARTHUR EDDINGTON are contenders.

name: Claude Bolling
subtitle: French pianist
blurb: The piano and flute compositions and prolific scoring career of CLAUDE BOLLING earn him the spot over SAMUEL GOLDFISH - an anglicized early version of the name of STUDIO HEAD Samuel Goldwyn's name, which was originally Shmuel Gelbfisz.

name: Astrud Gilberto
subtitle: Brazilian singer, Girl from Ipanema
blurb: A silky delivery and resume of bossa nova classics, leaves no doubt as to the Favourite for the AUIEO slot.

name: Austin Powers
subtitle: International Man of Mystery.
blurb: The Scrabble-leading JACQUIZZ RODGERS jumps up to number 2 in this spot, and makes the All-Time Name list - but can't topple the shagadelic spy.

name: Paul O'Neill
subtitle: Yankees/Reds Right fielder
blurb: Five World Series rings would clinch baseball player PAUL O'NEILL for the top slot over the eponymous Treasury Secretary. But mostly because you can add an I, and rearrange to form a manager he played for. (Hint: also a Yankee great, but managed him on the Reds).

name: Paul Scofield
subtitle: Best Actor 1968, A Man for All Seasons

name: Len Cariou
subtitle: US actor, Sweeney Todd
blurb: Joining PATTI LUPONE as a 1979 Tony winner, we met our 3rd supervocalic Sondheim performer and haven't even left the A's.

name: Benazir Bhutto
subtitle: Former Pakistani Prime Minister
blurb: One of two female former heads of state on our list.

name: Jean Cousin
subtitle: French Normand navigator
blurb: Sailed to Brazil in 1488 - 4 years before Columbus set sail. One of Cousin's got mad, and went to Spain where he sailed with Columbus. Cousin edges our Jean Louis who has 14 Oscar noms for costume design, and designed Marilyn Monroe's "Happy Birthday, Mr President" dress.

name: Earl Hutchinson
subtitle: US social commentator
blurb: The well-known African-American journalist generally uses his middle name, "Ofari", but even without that tops Pittsburgh Pirates GM Neil Huntington.

name: Bela Lugosi
subtitle: US actor, many horror films
blurb: Born Béla Ferenc Dezső Blaskó, he was a horror mainstay, but often played second billing to Boris Karloff, to his chagrin

name: Neil Mallon Bush
subtitle: US businessman, son of Pres. George HW Bush
blurb: Edging out New Christy Minstrel singer KEITH BARBOUR. Lebanese President EMIL LAHOUD also gets a mention, though his name is more commonly spelled EMILE.

name: Keith Godchaux
subtitle: US Keyboardist, Grateful Dead
blurb: Posthumous Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductee, 1994.

name: Keith Douglas
subtitle: UK Poet
blurb: Killed during invasion of Normandy.

name: Erik Gustafsson
subtitle: NHL player
blurb: Clearly this slot could use some new discoveries, but the 4-year NHL hockey pro must do for now.

name: Edith Tudor Hart
subtitle: Austrian-British photographer and spy
blurb: Studied with WALTER GROPIUS and became a Soviet spy. Never trust an Austrian-British photographer on the continent between two World Wars.

name: Leonard Whitcup
subtitle: US composer, wrote for Perry Como.
blurb: No disrespect to Mr. Whitcup, but this slot was not an easy fill.

name: Leonard Susskind
subtitle: US Physicist
blurb: One of the fathers of string theory.

name: Leonid Kravchuk
subtitle: First President of independent Ukraine
blurb: One of many supervocalic heads of state on our list. Two from Ukraine.

name: Leonid Kuchma
subtitle: Second President of independent Ukraine
blurb: Second back to back Ukrainian president. The pattern would not continue from here.

name: Greg Louganis
subtitle: US Diver, Olympic Gold medalist
blurb: No contenders with the gold medalist in the popularity department.

name: Fred Louis Wham
subtitle: US District Judge
blurb: We otherwise would not be including a regional judicial official appointed by Calvin Cooldge - but the name. How to account for it? Perhaps George Michael and Andrew Ridgely were inspired by one of his judicial decisions? Could have been. We may never know.

name: Deucalion
subtitle: Greek mythical figure, son of Prometheus

name: Beulah Bondi
subtitle: US Actress, It's a Wonderful Life
blurb: The Oscar™-nominated, Emmy-winning actress actually played Jimmy Stewart's mother in four - count 'em - four - movies. Quite a fortuitous niche, considering Stewart's wholesome image.

name: Edmund Richardson
subtitle: US Attorney, Clarence Darrow associate
blurb: Here we refer to Edmund Richardson the attorney, not the plantation owner. Here, a bit from one of his summations: "Which would you rather believe, this man on the stand wearing his cheap bravado and putting obloquy upon those who are innocent, or this husband and this father, an exemplary citizen all of his life?" Good stuff.

name: Greg Gugliotta
subtitle: US TV producer
blurb: Maybe he'll win an Emmy or something and get this slot off the schneid. Which is apparently an uncapitalized acceptable dictionary entry for "losing streak", derived from German card game idioms about a Schneider (i.e. a "poor tailor"). Just the etymological diversion his slot needed.

name: Ferguson Darling
subtitle: Title character's brother in Clarissa Explains It All
blurb: The brother of Clarissa Darling may not seem slot-worthy, but consider that the previous "winner" - Helmut Nodari - eked out one solitary IMDB listing in 1961. The EUOAI pattern was not conducive to names, apparently, with very few FESTUS's or EDMUNDs fitting the bill. Sometimes only a Helmut will fit.

name: Eudocia
subtitle: Byzantine Empress and Christian Saint
blurb: Regrettably, we retire the previous slot-holder SEQUOIA, creator of the written Cherokee alphabet. For his name: ᏎᏉᏯ - was transliterated it as "Sequoyah" in English. The "Sequoia" spelling came later when trees and other genuses were named. We welcome Byzantine Empress and Christian Saint EUDOCIA.

name: Michael Okwu
subtitle: US news correspondent, MSNBC/CNN.
blurb: Okwu has to get the blurb, so we can cite his legendary on-air observation: "We're all watching something that will never be repeated again. Michael Jackson will only die once." You can see this at 6:20 of the following Daily Show "Rippy Awards" clip.  Michael Gough - Alfred in the Tim Burton Batman movies, can't quite compete with that.

name: Michael Musto
subtitle: Michael Musto NY columnist, VillageVoice.
blurb: Niall Ferguson has indeed passed Musto since the original list was made, certainly in gravitas and appearance of intellect. Musto's gossipy omnipresence, however, keeps him atop the slot.

name: Pnina Rosenblum
subtitle: Israeli model and Knesset member
blurb: In a nod to gender equity, we promote Pnina Rosenblum, over NHL goalie Richard "No relation to Martin" Brodeur. His professional claim to fame was being the guy Wayne Gretzky scored on the most (29 goals). That would also seem to be the most anyone scored on anyone, which would take soe research to confirm. But which definitely affords the lovely and accomplished Ms. Rosenblum a win here.

name: Dilma Rousseff
subtitle: Former Brazilian Prime Minister
blurb: Regrettably, the female heads of state on our list have both come to ignominious ends, with Ms Rousseff indicted for corruption by the Brazilian senate.

name: Ita Buttrose
subtitle: Australian publisher and media executive
blurb: Ita Buttrose - an Australian Helen Gurley + Tina Brown rolled into one, takes this slot over our previous best - NZ stock car racer Brian Musgrove. Though we stay in the Down Under neighborhood.

name: Michel Aoun
subtitle: Current Lebanese President (2020)
blurb: Returned from exile since the writing of the original article, one of 2 Lebanese heads of state on our list, along with Emil(e) Lahoud

name: Birger Magnusson
subtitle: 13th century Swedish King
blurb: Of the House of Bjelbo, yet another head of state.

name: Mike Douglas
subtitle: US talk show host, 1964-1980
blurb: Tops DINESH D'SOUZA, whose incoherent political philosophy disqualifies him from serious consideration in the all-important wordplay context. Actor DIEGO LUNA will be a contender, next time we update the list.

name: Sir Edmund Barton
subtitle: Barton First Australian PrimeMinister, 1901-03.
blurb: 1st Prime Minister of Australia - Head of State

name: Ime Udoka
subtitle: NBA player and coach
blurb: IME UDOKA is our shortest *two-word* supervocalic. His unimpressive NBA career might be mooted if he is offered an NBA head coaching job. Stay tuned. Losing out is Horse Racing Hall of Famer, WINBERT MULHOLLAND, as well as DICK MEGUGORAC - a hot rodder and member of the LOW FLYERS RAING CLUB.

name: Dion Phaneuf
subtitle: Canadian NHL All-Star
blurb: Long-time NHL defenseman DION PHANEUF wins out over FRITZ KONRAD ERNST ZUMPT - whom we mention for obvious reasons, and who at 21 letters is the longest 4-word supervocalic name found in this exercise (quite possibly the only).

name: Phil Donahue
subtitle: US talk show host, 1967-.
blurb: The venerable and earnest PHIL DONAHUE takes the slot over Hollywood Golden Age actor VICTOR MATURE. Oddly, the scoring algorithm gives Mature the edge, which we'll have to look into.

name: Christopher Markus
subtitle: US screenwriter, Avengers: Endgame
blurb: Having scriven much of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, CHRISTOPHER MARKUS is - at this writing - the highest-grossing secreenwriters of all-time, along with his writing partner Stephen McFeely. See, you thought "Who's that?" but then there was the payoff.

name: Christopher Durang
subtitle: US Playwright, 1999 Obie for Beyond Therapy.
blurb: Playwright Durang remains a favorite as his Beyond Therapy describes what you just mightl require after too much time on this website. He tops longest 3-word, and overall longest supervocalic name CHRISTOPH ERNST LUTHARDT at 22 letters.

name: Rico Suave
subtitle: Title character in that song by Gerardo
blurb: Yes, we know "rico, suave" just means something like "rich and smooth", and yes we know that wasn't the shirtless guy's actual name - but you, me, and all of us thought it was, and given that the other option for this slot was an actual boy band singer - and a 3rd tier one at that... Rico Suave it is.

name: Sigurd Anderson
subtitle: Norwegian-born, South Dakota governor
blurb: In a tough slot, a legitimate US governorship can get you a win. So it is with old Sigurd Anderson, who came from the land of the ice and snow... to be governor of a place about as icy and snowy.

name: Shin Upagote
subtitle: Venerated Burmese arahant
blurb: Similar to Saints in the Catholic tradition, arahants are venerated for specific purposes - in this case for protection from storms. Such beatification tops comers like Sir Hugh Walople, who was known for  writing bildungsromane or novels of spiritual education.

name: Michu Meszaros
subtitle: World-famous little person
blurb: Some celebrities are welcome in any endeavor of trivia. MICHU is such a celebrity. When we discovered his last name fit this otherwise uninspiring slot, we quickly upgraded to include him. Dream big in Heaven, little man.

name: King Zu Geng of Shang
subtitle: King of the Shang Dynasty
blurb: Not always referred to exactly this way, but when he is... he represents a "Perfect 5" a 5-word supervocalic with one vowel per word.

name: Linus Roache
subtitle: UK actor, Wings of the Dove.
blurb: Present-day LINUS ROACHE over the similar-feeling British priest and troublemaker TITUS OATES. Quiz: He (Linus) could make anagrammatic history by appearing in what musical?

name: Wilbur Joseph Cash
subtitle: US Author, Mind of the South
blurb: Another tough slot (not so many WILBURs or SIGMUNDs out there). But author W.J. Cash does come through.
